    In the manufacturing processes, the following regulated substances listed in the RMP regulation are used as raw materials, made as intermediates or produced as products.

    Toxics:

        Anhydrous Ammonia
        Formaldehyde Solution
        Oleum (fuming sulfuric acid)
        Phosgene
        Sulfur Trioxide

   Flammables:

       Monomethylamine
       Dimethylamine
       Trimethylamine
       Dimethylether

Plant property where regulated substances are handled and processed is secured by fence and manned by security personnel at all times.

WORST-CASE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIO

     The worst-case release scenario for a toxic regulated substance is a failure of a storage tank containing anhydrous ammonia.  No mitgation is assumed.  This release has off-site impact as determined by use of the EPA OCA Guidance.

WORST-CASE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SECNARIO

     The worst-case release scenario for a flammable regulated substance is a failure of a storage tank containing dimethylamine.  No mitigation is assumed.  This release, if ignited, has off-site impact as determined by use of the EPA OCA Guidance and by computer modeling.

ALTERNATIVE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIOS

     There are five toxic regulated substance in the RMP.  These are anhydrous ammonia, formaldehyde solution, oleum, phosgene, and sulfur trioxide.  No mitigation is assumed in assessing off-site impact, except for the oleum release, which is contained in a dike.  The alternative release scenarios are summarized as follows.

        Anhydrous Ammonia - A leak in the ammonia distributi

on pipeline.

       Formaldehyde Solution - A leak from the formaldehyde storage tank transfer pump seal.

       Oleum - A leak of 20% oleum from the oleum tower tank.  The leak is contained in a diked area.

       Phosgene - A leak in the phosgene pipeline after a vaporizer releasing phosgene vapor.

       Sulfur Trioxide - A leak in the truck unloading line.

ALTERNATIVE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SECNARIO

     A release of Trimethylamine from a process transfer line.  The release results in a fireball.  No mitigation or administrative control is assumed.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMCIAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

     The DuPont Belle Plant processes follow the requirements of DuPont Corporate Safety, Health and Environmental (SHE) Standards S21A, "Process Safety Management".  This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.

The DuPont Belle Plant safety programs include:

Designing for Safety:
     *  A documented process technology system covering hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and         
        process design basis.
    *  Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located.
    *  Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.
    *  Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.
    *  Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.

Maintaining our Plant:
    *  Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.
    *  Contractors are trained and qualified.
    *  A work permit system controls hazards.

Operating Safely:
    *  Operators are trained and job qualified.
    *  Technical resources are available and utilized as required.
    *  Operators follow approved procedures.

Auditing our Operations:
    *  Routine safety inspections are conducted.
    *  Corporate, independent and governmental audits and reviews are conducted.
    *  Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

*  Critical safety equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical 
        integrity.
    *  Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to staring up any new or modified equipment.
    *  Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications.
    *  All incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.

THE FIVE-YEAR HISTORY

     No deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage have resulted from a release of any of the regulated chemcials from the covered processes under 40 CFR Part 68.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

     Plant personnel are trained and equipped to responsd to releases of the regulated substances.  The program is summarized as follows:

    *  Plant personnel receive emergency response training.
    *  Plant emergency responders are trained.
    *  Emergency response plans are current.
    *  Plant participates in emergency drills.
    *  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.
    *  The DuPont Belle Plant is a member of the local emergency planning committee.

If a Major Release Occurs:

    *  Emergency alarm is sounded.
    *  Plant Emergency Operating Center is activated.
    *  Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.
    *  Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate.

PLANT CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

As part of the Belle Plant process hazards review program, all processes are thoroughly reviewed on a specific periodic basis to identify risk reduction opportunities to improve safety.  As a result of these reviews, the following improvements are planned.

For Phosphorus Oxychoride:

    *  Upgrade interlock system for the unloading, storage and distribution of phosphorus chloride and
       upgrade emergency response and spill control procedures.

    *  Reduce consequences asso

ciated with a large vapor release from process equipment.
 
       NOTE:  The unit using Phosphorus Oxychloride has been shutdown.  These improvements will not be 
                   necessary.

For Anhydrous Ammonia:

    *  Upgrade controls and procedures to prevent "roll-over" and potential damage of the storage tank due 
       to unloading a large quantity of warm ammonia.
      
    *  Upgrade interlock system and safety design of boom and hydraulic cylinders on barge unloading.

    *  Implement program to periodically monitor equipment/foundation for differential settlement to prevent 
       excessive stress on equipment and potential damage.

    *  Upgrade pressure relief system on storage tank annular space.

    *  Improve integrity/reliability of flare that controls emission from storage tank.

    *  Upgrade transfer systems, processes and facilities to reduce the release quantity due to 
       catastrophic failure and limit off-site exposure.

    *  Upgrade the temperature control system to reduce the potential hazards of equipment overpressure
       and also to prevent low temperature ammonia from entering the transfer pipeline.

       NOTE:  These improvements have been completed.
